The Treasury Department has said that if there is an extension of government borrowing authority it would scale back federal employee pay in a bid to drive down federal expenditures and eventually balance the budget, a measure that has largely failed to gain much traction in partisan budget debates since the current government and the first-ever recession led the United States into a deep financial crisis.
Time was running out for Congress to stretch borrowing authority past March by the end of the month. Congress could at least look to extending current levels until June, the Treasury official said, adding that any extension of government borrowing authority himself opposed unbowed. He noted that January would be the most likely time to have another congressional facet to raise general authority of debt limit.

. Well, sort of. The city has approved a marijuana commercial ordinance with specific guidelines for where cannabis, dispensaries and pot farms are located. Those areas, according to the ordinance, are labeled as “green zones.” All together, the boundaries create a circle around Redwood City, meaning that there will be roughly 39 locations for dispensaries — but none within the circle.
The ordinance also states that 10 “commercial marijuana cultivation zones,” defined on the map as dark gray, are for cultivation, meaning only those within the zone can grow marijuana entrepreneurs.
Redwood City is not alone in its green zones approach: Los Angeles and Oakland have formulated similar guidelines for commercial cannabis where retailers and farms can be grown at a 300-foot distance from each other and 600 feet from a park.

. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men get hair loss no matter how tough on themselves they are. There even is a genetic predisposition. One’s environment also makes a huge impact. He says a bull-ringing scalp (where hair-free skin shows) groaning back against skull skin can create tissue damage. Your pulse may soar to as high as 300 beats a minute as you contest the pull, and hair probably will fall out, Fritz explains.

The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU labelling and approval regulation could be if it was properly planned, rolled out, and checked over time for effectiveness.
Its flaws are an example of how weakly it is administered once approved. And its low cost to public authorities means they may not pursue it when there may be financial or other incentives to turn a blind eye.
By law since 2012, in pursuit of EU law’s environmental goals, all new vehicles sold in the EU are examined at the end of their 5-year lifecycle to see if they complied with stringent vehicle emissions rules. Those that have exceeded the rules are rejected and banned.

larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners at a profit. As of May 2010, the average income of a web hosting business starts at about $2,500 per month, but can increase to as much as $8,000 or $12,000 per month, depending on the amount of server space sold.
Web hosting reseller companies purchase server space from larger web hosting providers. They are not allowed to sell server space directly to consumers. Certain terms and conditions may exist between reseller companies and other web hosting providers. Reselling accounts for about half of the income for a typical hosting control panel. You would be responsible for marketing and selling hosting accounts as a reseller, but you would still profit on the server space sold.

chemical herbicides, reduces waste, and allows soil to be healthier overall. To achieve optimal conditions with large amounts of compost or stored peat moss, you must understand and compensate for large temperature swings during composting times.
Many large amounts of organic material lined in row trays will often go 50° percent in a day or two, which can be very hot and cause decomposition ! It is not easy to have one set temperature over time with that much material. If the temperature swings by more than about 10-15°, decomposition will slow, so keep the soils cool at those different highs. To reduce the temperature differences, wetting the rods every 3rd day or so will help.

professionals in finance, property management and health care with complex choices. The mapping process of a decision tree reflects the probability of the decisions' outcomes.
Finance professionals use a decision tree to reflect possible actions based on possible upside and downside events. Options within the tree represent investment risk, such as Washington Mutual dealing with the probability of rising interest rates causing customers to take out loans elsewhere. One option could be to buy a mortgage-backed security as a hedging mechanism against future loan losses, or the option can be to build a financial risk model and consider other remedy options. Finance companies typically turn to decision trees when markets are fluid, in times of extensive money losses, interest-rate changes or markets prone to extreme volatility.
A decision framework is also a decision tree model rather than an exact tool. This model is helpful for a project that has high volumes of data. Among the high

Vanderbilt Health aims to create “value-based care,” a model in which healthcare providers assume financial risk for patients they care for.
An overall national goal of health plans is to move to value-based care and hold providers accountable for patient health, but this new partnership will, essentially, provide Tennessee residents statewide value-based care, a spokesman at UT said Wednesday (Dec. 6). The new group is currently the first of its kind formed entirely by physicians and does not include large health insurance companies or hospitals, the article notes. Under this model, healthcare plans will reimburse providers at a set, often higher, rate, rather the current “fee-for-service” model where doctors’ fee are derived based on the number of services they provide.

Previously, non-military caregivers, such as family members of loved ones with Alzheimer’s, ALS and Parkinson's, could be certified for FMLA by a physician under the general rules. One class of supernovae is type Ia, which are stellar explosions exhibited when an object such as a star undergoes a thermonuclear chemical reaction. These are associated with little variability in the luminosity of about 5000 distance solar symbols, which led scientists early on to conclude that they were related to nebulae of extended matter. Drive-thru inspections: In Florida, the rental cars are legally required to undergo an inspection before delivering to customer and another inspection after returning the car. These are required and mandatory, meaning they have to do it even though it may not be in your interest to do the same. The inspectors will leave a copy of their inspection with you for your records and, if you disagree with the findings, you can have your car re-inspected. What Senate rules govern the elections of Replacement Senators?
The U.S. Constitution gives state legislatures the sole right to determine U.S. Senate "Vacancies," either through direct appointment or direct election. Versions of Article I in the state constitutions prescribe that the "Governor" appoint delegates "on the advice and consent of both houses of the legislature, as aforesaid," or that state legislatures appoint their replacement members to "[f]ill a vacancy during the recess of the legislature" from a list that includes certain

Bulgaria does have an expert committee that advises the authorities on matters pertaining to environmental planning and establishing strategic goals, but unlike the French system, it cannot make binding decisions with far reaching consequences.
Legislator Anelia Perisacheva said that the first step of the process will be the establishment of a commission which would provide the Parliament with a vision of how the system would function in practice. poetry of Coleridge (English Heritage _Programme Study Notes_, 17). What is above nature? When the laws of nature are broken? Or when a person seems to have transcended the circumstances of his life, surmounting biography, which is the story of accidents, illness, misfortune, in order to establish a new identity that transcends it? The drama So Many Gifts by Stephen Kick transcended nature by inverting repeatable text to make new content, affirming the equation of cause with effect. The act of making a poem, sending it off in slippery globules and trusting that another voice knit them loosely in invisible lines deeper than hours or borders is the everyday miracle of the poet. As the threat of internal corruption dogs the ranks of border security forces throughout the United States, the Obama administration is contemplating deploying lower-level agents to Mexico for temporary tours away from their typical repair runs along the border.
According to several people with knowledge of the idea and a draft request for help, Customs and Border Protection (CPB) officials are advocating for regular rotations -- anywhere from three to six months -- of low-ranking Customs agents all over Mexico to work on crime issues.
Like sending National Guard troops to the war in Iraq as a way to keep Mexico's drug lords at bay, such a move to bring agents south would help strengthen the relationship between the two countries and make it more difficult for the drug trade to buy officials in either place, security experts say.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and the Democratic president.
The Treasury Department has said that if there is an extension of government borrowing authority it would scale back federal employee pay in a bid to drive down federal expenditures and eventually balance the budget, a measure that has largely failed to gain much traction in partisan budget debates since the current government and the first-ever recession led the United States into a deep financial crisis.
Time was running out for Congress to stretch borrowing authority past March by the end of the month. Congress could at least look to extending current levels until June, the Treasury official said, adding that any extension of government borrowing authority himself opposed unbowed. He noted that January would be the most likely time to have another congressional facet to raise general authority of debt limit.

Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America. He declared the nation is primed for change and called on lawmakers to show leadership.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely. Ireland ranked highest for maternal mortality with 18 deaths per 100,000 births in 2015 according to the latest statistics from the World Health Organization, while Sweden ranked lowest at two. The United States was the only country to see a rise in its death rate at five, and most other countries besides Ireland; all saw mortality rates fall from 2000 to 2015, according to a recent study in The Lancet Global Health.
However, the reasons for this trend in the US would still be startling. In the most industrialised country in the world, maternal deaths have actually been on the rise since 1990, according to a new study in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology, going against the global trend. Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue increased 6% in dollar terms to $6.42 billion (3.16 pounds, 4.02 euros), while total merchandise wholesale revenue gained 6% to $5.40 billion. Same-store sales rose 4%, helped by double-digit gains in basketball and running.
Structural cost cuts and a decision last year to boost sales in China by growing wholesale partners has been reflected in the number of margins. The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together and told them of his chronic back problems. The coach lifted his chain and showed it held a chunk of bone where a knife slice had gone deep. He told them he wasn't walking on to that field.
''If we could lose this thing to Neville,'' Gray said to them, ''a lot of other people could go to hell on earth!''
Gray ordered them to get off the sidelines, put on helmets and Sunday suits and play the game.
''There must be something inside that pushes people on,'' said Gray's son Terry, a member of the 1981 National Championship team. ''It says something about the guys who get pushed and who can push harder.''
Granted, asking a mere 18 players to take on 12 teammates from an all-white high school that was both skilled and bigger than the Vikings was a tall order.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come only through a profound overhaul of business and consumption practices worldwide. That is according to new UNCTAD (United Nations Conference on Trade and Development) eco-tariffs for over 1000 products, which force consumers in rich countries to pay more for what they consume.
However, both public pressure and political will may well be needed to skew traditional markets – currently driven by maximal profitability – towards sustainability.
“In the policy considerations that lie behind the eco-tariffs of the new report are three potential game changers. By prioritising efficiency, by boosting renewables in transport, through subsidy reform and education, individuals and countries can start reducing negative externalities of their consumption, says Andreas Rechkemmer, the Director of UNCTAD’s Trade and Environment Section, leading the new assessments for this year’s report.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a favorite for the ducks to hang out at because of the little puddle, according to Don Shell, who was in the area on Thursday.
Shell, who keeps tabs on resident ducks like Donald, said he met a guy with his grandson playing with them when the ducks were found.
Shell took a sledgehammer to pop the ducks' bills off the cable and to let them drink. Some ducks had a lot of blood drawn and had metabolic challenges because of it, but Shell says all of the ducks are are still gamely enjoying the water and will probably not suffer any lasting effects.
The ducks would stay confined to the park all day and then go back out at night, according to city plans.
Shell says he did not find Stranded Guys in the area, and he isn’t sure who the culprits are. More news about the area

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on Wednesday effectively rejected two proposed conservative initiatives to repeal or amend the Liberals' signature climate measures.
Carr told a news conference in Edmonton that the federal carbon tax is an “unavoidable part” of the economic future.
He also took a swipe at Ontario Premier Doug Ford, a vocal conservative who has vowed he will fight the federal plan.
Carr dismissed outright the Ford government’s arguments that the system, which requires fuel and electricity producers in Ontario, Alberta and British Columbia to pay for extra emissions reductions, has hurt the economy.
“I just want to say to the people of Ontario that you’ve got one of the highest sustainable asset bases because of your clean air and clean water,” he said.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been charged in Iran with espionage, started in Tehran, according to his lawyer. Four more journalists have been arrested since Mr. Rezaian’s, and although Iran routinely holds such people in pretrial detention, that situation is threatens to become longer than two years as Iran’s ruling clerical commune fails to decide which charge is most damning. In addition to how long the current prisoners are held in pretrial limbo, it’s hard to reconcile how Iran democidized human rights at the end of 2009 while at the beginning of the year it rules out espionage charges for itself. If convicted on the holding charges, Mr. Rezaian faces up to ten additional years of imprisonment.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered new rules on the use of both groundwater and surface water to make sure the state was well-prepared for the current drought.
Also Friday the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced it is ending a lengthy five-year coastal waters starvation event in California.

Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 8:50 p.m. and city officials said the flames spread quickly through the residence.
At least ten people living in the 12-unit apartment building were displaced by the fire.
Six people were taken to local hospitals, including the boy and a woman with a temporary roofing injury, according to Fire Media Affairs Official Larry Campbell
The victim was not originally reported as a boy by fire officials, but CPD said he was dead on arrival.

He graduated from prep school at 17 and moved into Yale University when he was just 18 years old, studied fraternity woodcraft (read plumbing) to fulfill the fraternity bid, and graduated four years later in 1948 at the age of 22 with a degree in Economics. TAYCHEEDAH - Two men were seriously injured Thursday night in a head-on crash in the town of Taycheedah.
A 35-year-old Fond du Lac man was traveling northbound on Highway 45 in the left lane when the vehicle drifted across the centerline and struck another vehicle head-on just outside of Taycheedah, according to a Wisconsin State Patrol news release.
The crash happened about 9:05 p.m. west of Taycheedah.
When emergency crews arrived they found two men trapped. One was trying to get free by smashing out the back window. The other man was confused from the crash and unable to communicate, said State Patrol Officer Kate Lancour.

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference on Monday.
Peter Gutmann, whose papers have covered security, playback of audio and video files, and Flash bypass, spoke at the conference on Monday. He criticized Microsoft, saying that the company's "bare wire setup" is letting uncountable even encrypted audio frequencies through the listening processes in Windows Vista.
"The harmful effects of this poor playback are largely anecdotal, and there doesn't seem to be any metric that gathers that data actively. They are losing good customers because their sound is cracking and people are complaining that it doesn't sound as good," Gutmann said.
However, components like Media Foundation "do not add benefits, they add hazards. And they are blinding people to what is really going on, until the day of reckoning comes along, and I think it does now," Gutmann added.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 25-26 November Asean summit.
Minister of Information and Culture Bouasy Inthiltha assured reporters of Alaing Khamphavong and Pak Son Dasouvannavong the new rules would not affect their coverage of the summit, which is to be held in Vientiane to commemorate 25 years of strategic alliances between Lao PDR and its partners in Asean. He said media groups would be accredited and journalists would not be detained if they comply with the rules.
On Friday, Lao officials summoned Asean diplomatic representatives to explain the modified regulations. Earlier the foreign correspondents’ bureau of Lao PDR sent a letter asking for clarification but received no response.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by competitor JetBlue Airways Corp. The fee will be in place even for name-brand customers traveling in "Executive First," which until now offered first-class amenities such as complimentary beer and wine with meals, easy access to a premium lounge at major airports, check baggage fees waived and no seat-cost surcharges. Both Chicago-based companies will give travel industry training and skills workshops through their Northwest Airlines property at a two-year, $65 million (U.S.) contract. Northwest has been trying to raise plane ridership after suffering financial setbacks from the entry of low-cost airlines in its Midwestern hub-city markets. SourceScott Hettrick, Tribune staff reporter. Copyright Chicago Tribune.

For several years, Congress mandated Montana spend match dollars on a University of Montana center that collected statistics and information on domestic violence in Montana, but the programs ran out of matching funds and were jettisoned because of funding issues. The state Legislature is now in the process of funding a new project through the University of Montana’s Native Center, which would mirror statistics that the antiquated center fulfilled.

ZeeMee allows students to crowdsource a summary of their lives in an app that follows trust, authenticity, privacy and security models familiar on other platforms.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal dimension of this creative and expressive discipline to the register of soporific escapism, saying that art is always a form of illusion, of illusion and forgetting and naivety. Yet, as last week’s attacks on religious and political symbols in India have shown us too clearly: just as senseless destruction of valuable antiquities is another crime of human history, the beauty and light we project upon all understanding might best be cultivated in our small daily choices with regard to the cultivation of our language, their collection and our care. Proximity between us can break down the usual divide we permit that distances us from ourselves. This happens when we shift our focus inwards, to allow expressions welling up in us, responses prior to all words, an intimation of the world, of what lies before our lives. The lines that simultaneously emerge, move through us and become words in their utterance, only then begin to form our way. Go

Courtesy Redwood City. On Monday, April 9, the city of Redwood City approved an ordinance allowing cannabis business only in the green zone on this map.
Redwood City is open for cannabis business. Well, sort of. The city has approved a marijuana commercial ordinance with specific guidelines for where cannabis, dispensaries and pot farms are located. Those areas, according to the ordinance, are labeled as “green zones.” All together, the boundaries create a circle around Redwood City, meaning that there will be roughly 39 locations for dispensaries — but none within the circle.
The ordinance also states that 10 “commercial marijuana cultivation zones,” defined on the map as dark gray, are for cultivation, meaning only those within the zone can grow marijuana entrepreneurs.
Redwood City is not alone in its green zones approach: Los Angeles and Oakland have formulated similar guidelines for commercial cannabis where retailers and farms can be grown at a 300-foot distance from each other and 600 feet from a park.

COLUMBIA, SC (WIS) - James Robert Thomason has owned his liquor store since 2002.
Right now, Thomason’s Wine and Liquor, just like any other liquor store, can only sell alcohol between 10 AM and 7 PM, but Thomason wants to know why he’s not only allowed, but has been selling more liquor later on at night.
“I’d get off at, say, midnight after switching over and then my sales on five would be higher, on the other five showed an increase overall,” Thomason said. “For every dollar I spent, I got $2 back.”
That’s right. Thomason was funding those after-hours sales by making sure the registers and cameras were up and running even as he left the business. And at 80 cents a minute, those sales would end up costing him more than $2,800 for just one night. Thomason has kept track every night just so he can see with his own eyes how many late night crimes have happened around his business.

Citing “concurrent exposures to other pesticides” rather than glyphosate itself, the dialback projections “point to an urgent need,” they wrote, for more research into cancer clusters “among pesticide applicators.”
The study noted that “certain weed-suppression techniques, such as new machinery technologies,” could reduce or even eliminate the need for pesticides in some situations.
For example, dinting the soil with sulphur discourages weed growth without reducing needed crop nutrients. For farmers who harvest corn and cotton for silage, “applying grain legume forages, including as cover crops ... could stimulate plant growth, reducing the record nitrogen requirements provided by expensive fertilizer while inhibiting corn root disease and weed infestations.”

A failure to scan outsourced medical records has caused an approximate three- to five-month backlog at the Memphis Veteran Administration Medical Center, The Daily Caller has learned.
TheDC was exclusively given a copy of the class-action lawsuit.
For the past three months, patients’ faxes and letters have been kept in the VA’s Medical Records Folder, which is called the MMR by the VA. According to the attorney for the outsourcing company, Office Practicum, the incomplete data caused the VA’s processing ability to drop from hundreds or thousands of fax calls a day to just about ten or twelve fax calls per day. The new record keeping system maintained by the VA did not match Office Practicum’s records.
The VA contracted Office Practicum, located in Fort Worth, Texas, with their scanning outsourcing service in 2011. Records submitted to the company and then exported to the VA, on a case by case basis, were purposely supposed to remain unedited following Office Practicum’s scanning.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Renaissance. His reputation is today overshadowed by Giordano Bruno (1546–1600), who continued his project of offering a unified system, and even in part anticipated the project of Descartes. However, Proclus's entire writings have recently been published in critical editions from the Oxford series “Thesaurus Philopl. Gr.), and some articles have been published as well. His Theology ii unknown, but might be expected to form part of the Zurich Thesaurus. Two articles have been published on Proclus in Monumenta Nossanchie. A book in French (On Proclos) will be published this winter.

Blackpool Symphony Orchestra continues its 2017/18 season with a concert celebrating the arrival of spring.
The performance, under the baton of Helen Harrison, takes place on Saturday 7.30pm at Stanley-Brown High Bicker Hall. Rehearsals begin at 7pm.
Featured works include Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky’s Swan Lake Waltz, Johann Strauss II’s Blue Danube Waltz, and Gerry Taylor’s Thrush in a Silver Cage – yes, an orchestra playing bird noises. For the finale, there will be Sergei Polinovski and Sergei Prokofiev’s popular Peter and the Wolf showpiece.
A choir is also taking part, and singers should arrive promptly at 7pm to prepare. They make their entrance when the first movement – Spring, depicting a relaxed rural scene without fog – yields to Summer.
Choir members should bring a key song sheet if possible to expedite rehearsal.
Tickets are £12 and concessions £5.

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border if their names match those on a federal “no-fly list” of more than 80 countries.
Citizens from Australia, Japan and the United States already have to give the biometric information. All three allies are signatories of Canada’s Global Passport Offences (PRO).
Canada says the move to harness more people’s data, takes its effort to dismantle foreign criminal gangs beyond its usual attacks on their recruiting.
Uneasiness about information security in the post-Edward-Snowden era could bring travel to a halt, critics said. But Canada’s innovative push into big data is being widely praised as being ahead of the times, especially considering it’s being taken together by air and land border.
“It is a significant positive change in the fight against criminal and terrorist threats to Canada,” Public Safety Minister Steve Blaney said in a statement.

KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original Balinese and others in Indonesia fought side-by-side with the Allies during World War I, and their offspring flocked to have their faces carved to mourn the demise of that ideal.
The tough symbolism has seemed a necessary contrast to the struggle of many Balinese, who like other Javanese communities say they are left despised and forgotten in poor and remote villages, despite huge expectations.
Mr Budihersada had simplified what he thought to be a dimensional but appealing symbol from Bali to incorporate wider meanings of struggle and suffering by removing shadows and obscurities.

(CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Michael Guerico (R) and Sheldon (Chuck) Everett had challenged the constitutionality of Mississippi’s Lethal Injection Procedures in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, where they say a component of the procedure was approved before any challenge to Mississippi’s formulation of the execution medicine was raised.
U.S. Circuit Judge Kathleen Williams added that the pair should consider themselves lucky that they were not executed by Mississippi’s methods before their inability to bring forth any challenge in court was discovered. Three other death row inmates likewise tried to resist the lethal injection, but their challenge failed when the U.S. Supreme Court issued a decision two hours after they could have joined the lawsuit.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few points of business envelope etiquette to keep in mind.
Your business envelope is a formal means of communicating with a recipient. Addressing it appropriately shows you value your time and the time of the recipient, as well as your willingness to adhere to important content. If you don’t write the address on a plain white or cream-colored bifold letter in ink that matches any markings or customization of the company’s corporate monogram or logo, then you run the risk of creating an amateur-looking piece of correspondence.

CLEVELAND – Two women -- one with a ticket, one tearfully without -- laid claim to a $162 million lottery jackpot Tuesday, triggering a legal dispute that could come down to "finder's keepers" rules.
Jean LePera of Garfield Heights, Ohio, had the ticket when she lost it close to getting her prize. Lula Mills of Galloway, N.J., found it in her cappuccino.
The dispute has underscored questions about what happens when people lose a winning ticket, cutting the weeks after a big drawing from search parties and emotional reunions with lucky ticket-holders to lawyers and lawsuits. Other big payouts have also been challenged in court, but rarely has one been the subject of drama only hours after it was won.
For days, Mills had commuted from New Jersey to Minnesota -- a field office where $42 million worth of winnings were sold Jan. 6 -- where television cameras recorded her excitement and relief as lottery officials picked her cardpunched $426 million winning ticket.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men get hair loss no matter how tough on themselves they are. There even is a genetic predisposition. One’s environment also makes a huge impact. Dealing with physical or emotional stress can cause a thinned-out head of hair, Fritz says. He says a bull-ringing scalp (where hair-free skin shows) groaning back against skull skin can create tissue damage. Your pulse may soar to as high as 300 beats a minute as you contest the pull, and hair probably will fall out, Fritz explains.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear infections, bronchitis, and throat infections. It can also treat lung infections such as pneumonia, as well as skin and wound infections when other antibiotics are ineffective.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they looked like fun, but their performance was little better than a pair of regular spectacles.
This image from Massachusetts General Hospital reveals “flowmobile” cells with an infrared camera for detection of melanoma.
Thankfully, medical technology has come light years from the black and white images produced by cathode-ray tubes found in many a Radar O’Reilly, but devices known as hyperspectral cameras promise detailed analysis of everything from concrete bridges and drinking water to body scanning and extreme sports monitoring.
One such hyperspectral camera, unveiled recently by researchers of the Fraunhofer Institute in Germany, is a special handheld device capable of ultrafine 3-D monitoring of everything from building inspection to cadaver detection and locomotive maintenance. Hyperspectral imaging has been used for years to help assess structural flaws on infrastructure

The Financial Post’s Geoff Zochodne did a sweep of the big banks’ economists on Oct. 1 and found that the received wisdom now is that the Bank of Canada will quicken its march to a more accommodative policy stance than originally planned.
All but one of the economists expects mid-2011, before the formal announcement of the 2012 budget, to see a cut in the key overnight rate to three per cent, the lowest level since 2007. That’s a quarter-per-cent less than what they said last year at this time, when there were growing tensions between the United States and North Korea.

TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380 along Route 643.
Last year, twenty PennDOT Public Information centers installed surveillance boxes in the units to keep an eye on trouble spots in our area.
Work is scheduled to last until Thanksgiving.
PennDOT officials say the work should help prevent fatal accidents, such as the one on I-380 on Thanksgiving Day morning that left five people in a vehicle and one person walking dead.
One of the five people who lost their lives was a PennDOT maintenance motor grader operator. A memorial trees and plaques have also been placed in southern Bucks County.
For more information from PennDOT on Interstate 380 as well as other projects you can follow this link.

The total VR market will generate $5.1 billion this year, new report claims.
2016 is poised to be the year that virtual reality really gets going, as Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR and HTC Vive begin to converge in a battle to win over hearts and minds. Next week, Google and Microsoft will also add their specialist headsets to the mix. Analysts expect that the global VR market will rise from $328 million this year to $5.1 billion in 2017. IDC commissioned the report, and there is certainly optimism about VR uptake. The firm believes that VR will generate around 50% of total tech spending within the home entertainment industry. Gamble was dropped off at Northwestern Memorial Hospital with gunshot wounds shortly before 10:50 p.m. Sunday in the South Chicago section on the city's Far South Side, authorities said. He was pronounced dead at 11:26 p.m., according to a statement from police.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and eventually faced the execution order, is one of his or her own times' most venerated figures among Christians, well deserving of all the attention for his stand against “going along with the crowd,” as one translation of the title of his resistance-era memoir puts it.
But with other major Christian figures (Jesus; Paul; John Calvin, etc.), who have become books of theology or inspiring pamphlets for living, Bonhoeffer is a rarer figure—one tended to when biography meets with theology, and then chiefly concerned with Bonhoeffer's theology, not his faith. The book life of the man can get lost in the dust of admiration for, say, Cost of Discipleship. CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farag, who wrote a column in Reuters in 2012, was arrested on Saturday near Empress Tahia mosque in central Cairo, his wife Huda told Reuters.
"There were about five or six people carrying out mass arrest operations and a very bad smell was coming form some vehicles nearby," he said.
All three said Farag was taken to a detention centre on Six of October road in Cairo, the street nearest the house of Huda's relatives. There they were told he would spend the night as a detainee.
Authorities have come under increasing pressure in recent days amid nationwide protests by motorcyclists demonstrating against violence against them by policemen.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know exactly why it is you want to work for the company.
Your answer should include where you expect to be in your career five years from now and what is required to position you towards that goal. Compare what the company offers with your short-term and long-term career plans. Your answer should also reveal what skills, traits and knowledge you believe you can provide to benefit the company and how your desire for the job will contribute to both you and the organization.
To help you get ready to answer this often-thoughtful question in a job interview, we’ve compiled 10 more-specific things you should consider including in your answer.

The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's head count from 390 to 276. The layoffs will take place over a few weeks, the company said.
Aduro laid off roughly 20 percent of its workforce from that same job level in May, after announcing plans to shutter its bench site — Trius Therapeutics — following regulators concerns that its lead drug is not without risks. Last month, the FDA turned down the company's application to sell its lymphoma drug Tx609 as it was not satisfied with clinical trial results.

Emigrated Cubans in the US city of Miami, Florida, are preparing today for a debate on August 26 about the new Constitution project of their native country.
That meeting, the first of three planned for the same purpose, will be held at one of Miami's Catholic churches where most Cubans converge after leaving the island.
The new Constitution was approved in Cuba during a referendum on February 24, however the final text will not be known until two other meetings are completed in the coming weeks.
Cubans desire to learn how the text will affect daily life, among other aspects.
Since 2012, when President Raul Castro announced that a Constitutional reform would be in place by 2019, the debate over different stages has sparked a massive migration of emigrated Cubans to Florida.
On May 31, the first stage on the draft was held, receiving close to 770 000 signatures.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU labelling and approval regulation could be if it was properly planned, rolled out, and checked over time for effectiveness.
Its flaws are an example of how weakly it is administered once approved. And its low cost to public authorities means they may not pursue it when there may be financial or other incentives to turn a blind eye.
By law since 2012, in pursuit of EU law’s environmental goals, all new vehicles sold in the EU are examined at the end of their 5-year lifecycle to see if they complied with stringent vehicle emissions rules. Those that have exceeded the rules are rejected and banned.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 31 to 30 late vote Friday, making Colorado the first state to create such a system even before it begins broader marijuana sales in January 2014.
"It's common-sense policy — not revolutionary policy. Common-sense policy," Democratic Sen. Pat Steadman told foxsnowdenver.com.
Colorado law currently allows commercial pot sales to card-carrying users over 21 years old, but gives the federal government authority to crack down if distributors openly handle cash. Cara DeGett, top DEA official in Colorado, has frequently nixed notions about improving banking policies.

Fed policymakers lifted rates on 15 March and Powell said during his testimony on Tuesday that they intended several further hikes in the coming year to continue steady gradual rate increases.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by Dutchman Bull de Kogelle 108 years and five months after it was lost, with a note in response.
It has been confirmed the bottle came from the lost Belgian ship Elberfeld and was named for one of its last ports, Chicago.
By coincidence the present bottle was opened not too far from where the ship sunk on 17 February 1886 on its way to Norway and the Netherlands.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners at a profit. As of May 2010, the average income of a web hosting business starts at about $2,500 per month, but can increase to as much as $8,000 or $12,000 per month, depending on the amount of server space sold.
Web hosting reseller companies purchase server space from larger web hosting providers. They are not allowed to sell server space directly to consumers. Certain terms and conditions may exist between reseller companies and other web hosting providers. Reselling accounts for about half of the income for a typical hosting control panel. You would be responsible for marketing and selling hosting accounts as a reseller, but you would still profit on the server space sold.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Fatality Rate was 2.1 deaths per 1000 births in 2012. This figure is down slightly from somewhere between the range of 2-2.3 during 1989 and 2000, showing modest improvement nationally, but world health rankings assessed by Science magazine show that in the U.S., the neonatal mortality rate of deaths within a month of birth, compares poorly to other countries like Israel, Japan, or France. Can this problem be fixed? According to Julian E. Koles, M.D., a Maternal-Fetal Medicine specialist at Jerusalem Medical Centre and Hobe Sound Bible Church, yes, but more work must be done. The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite North Carolina’s renewable-energy goal.
Environmentalists have now criticized the plan as lacking detail and unclear on how certain practices, like solar panels on public lands, might be implemented.
Legislation authorizing the program — passed by the General Assembly last month— says the power purchasing program is critical as zero-emissions renewables face new federal tax rules.
“There is a looming deadline of December 31, when 25 percent of the green energy tax credit sunsets,” said Randy Wheeless, president of the North Carolina Sustainable Energy Association. The program creates a set of tools to help the regulated monopolies meet a portion of power purchasing goals approved by the legislature last year.

BAGNERES-DE-LUCHON, France (Reuters) - The Tour de France is set for its moment of truth on Wednesday as the peloton prepares for a brutal 17th stage and potentially decisive psychological blow through the Pyrenees.
Despite the advantage enjoyed by the general classification favourites for most of the race, the penultimate day could spark the most dramatic stage of a contest which has had more twists and turns than usual.
America's Tejay van Garderen joined a list of luckless protagonists that has choked the once immortal Belgian Eddy Merckx of victories with a crash in Tuesday's sixth stage.
Until then it had seemed the 25-year-old BMC Racing Team cyclist could grab centre stage after snatching a second-place on Saturday in the shortest stage in history.
On Wednesday, the peloton face five long category one and two climbs with two of them in turn each just five kilometres from the finish, setting up a psychologically advantageous hunt among the leading contenders.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy produced in Earth’s interior. It is thought that primordial energy comes from radioactive elements that are created late in Earth’s formation.
Recent evidence suggests Earth’s energy budget, the balance between heatflow emanating from Earth’s interior and that supplied by inputs of primordial and nuclear energy, is about 40% higher than previously estimated.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a tumor the microscopic piece of skin 37 times before it could become cancerous. This likely means there’s a window of time fur-trimmers and elephant fans have to help the creature out.
“Elephants possess a tremendous self-repairing capacity,” said anesthesiologist Gary Small, who co-authored the study with zoologist Kenton R. Rinehart.
The researchers treat 24 baboon nurses with psoriasis at South African Park near Durabong during the 1970s. They found a 31% reduction in cancer four years after dosing them with cannabisoiol. This data was gathered after studying baboons for a decade.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Diane Smith family Yuma Center measured brain responses to complicated tasks among yoga practitioners and controls after they practiced 20 minutes of yoga or went through a similar but non-yogic “social comparison” task.
The study is described this month in an article entitled "Neural basis of initial and repeat-sidedness of yoga" in the International Journal of Yoga Therapy.
Previous research had shown that yoga was associated with more gray matter visuospatial processing in the right hemisphere – literally the dominant hemisphere we typically use when operating two-handed tools such as a Swiss Army knife. The new study stretched and then correlated additional neural responses that accompanied the exercise of specific skills fairly shortly afterward by exploring how participants remembered certain exercises they were already familiar with, and how they responded to unfamiliar ones. New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took voluntary financial disclosures from 22 companies—energy producers, resources, and manufacturing—from 2016’s Financial Reporting Council annual general meeting. A big picture analysis concluded four in every 10 companies “could not meet the Paris Climate Goals if the enhanced climate commitments set by the US were adopted internationally.”
Only 14, including ANZ, QBE, IAG, RioTinto, Santos and Telstra are actively working to reach the goals of the Paris agreement and are “domestic leaders.”

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical herbicides, reduces waste, and allows soil to be healthier overall. To achieve optimal conditions with large amounts of compost or stored peat moss, you must understand and compensate for large temperature swings during composting times.
Many large amounts of organic material lined in row trays will often go 50° percent in a day or two, which can be very hot and cause decomposition ! It is not easy to have one set temperature over time with that much material. If the temperature swings by more than about 10-15°, decomposition will slow, so keep the soils cool at those different highs. To reduce the temperature differences, wetting the rods every 3rd day or so will help.
Core material for large areas

The customer may not always be right. What are some circumstances where they could be wrong?
In a recent trip to a grocery store, I grabbed a few items on the way out. Actually two or three of items arrived in a bag that was so light I almost couldn’t carry it. Delivering the same bag – maybe one or two items heavier – would have definitely helped. I griped to the cashier, saying I felt I was being short-changed.
I won’t name names, but I'll go out of my way to prevent the experience next time. To customers, complaining about things like packaging and attentiveness can just sound like complainin’. I know I don’t need to nitpick, but I’m interpreting that as a cue from the other guy to put a little more care into things. Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow, a food writer in England.
His Vietnam War book, “In Our Image: America’s Empire in the Philippines,” won the Pulitzer Prize in 1989. He wrote that book while going blind while living in London after the conflict and war he covered in Asia, a conflict he called the “most horrifying chapter of America’s wars in Asia.” A TV documentary about the Vietnam conflict he made with his son Mark Karnow and the Associated Press won the national Emmy award after being broadcast on WNET Channel 13.

LAVALLETTE, N.J. (CBSNewYork) – A Jersey shore town is determined to always remember a teen whose life was cut short in a senseless murder.
With bags of cement in hand, dozens of students came to the Villa Joseph Marie Senior High School and they, in a way, built up a community.
Cement from the school’s entire senior class was spread behind the cross at the entrance of the Villa Joseph Marie Memorial Stairway Walk in honor of Caligan Carr.
“Remembering her every time I pass by here, even just to look at the cross,” sophomore Amelia Duprey-Farrell said.
Carr’s mother, Rosa Carr, wanted the cement pouring to take place over the entire weekend so relatives could share the ceremony for their daughter.
Carr was just 17 years old when she died in April.
“And if we were to have another day like that in the future, that gives me hope,” Carr said while standing behind the newly poured cement.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in finance, property management and health care with complex choices. The mapping process of a decision tree reflects the probability of the decisions' outcomes.
Finance professionals use a decision tree to reflect possible actions based on possible upside and downside events. Options within the tree represent investment risk, such as Washington Mutual dealing with the probability of rising interest rates causing customers to take out loans elsewhere. One option could be to buy a mortgage-backed security as a hedging mechanism against future loan losses, or the option can be to build a financial risk model and consider other remedy options. Finance companies typically turn to decision trees when markets are fluid, in times of extensive money losses, interest-rate changes or markets prone to extreme volatility.

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the light around noon last Saturday, dashing away the hopes of one of several independent groups set up to mine the gem.
Three miners were rescued, but a few hours later officials called a halt because of safety concerns. Police said almost no unaccounted miners have surfaced.
About 80 miners were thought to have been in the mine 60 kilometres (40 miles) from Myanmar’s second city of Mandalay, said Wat Htar Aung, a member of the Unity Generation Group, the only authorised jade-mining cartel in Mogok.
Co-founder Nay Myo Win said the manganese deposit is located under 35-metre (100-foot) high mountain side, one of many such outcrops in the area.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. It works like clone stamp except it measures where your visual data is lacking, then intelligently erases that data from the source image, conveniently leaving the background layers alone. This means you can easily apply a translucent texture of a background onto a photo of a wall only around the objects on that wall instead of the entire background area.
The feature aims to alleviate a part of the tediousness of image manipulation: detail devoted to filling in the quiet, rather than important, parts where information might be lacking. This tool (like many) employs machine learning to accelerate the process of image editing, possibly while emulating some more complex creative choices. Fully-automatic amelioration of backgrounds seems rather crucial because the alternative means working at a more base computational level. The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, on the App Store under the category ‘poems’ (see map). As would be expected, the poem’s language is archaic, stylistically broken. Yet microfiction author and Web consultant Esther Gwendolyn Bénintji has demonstrated that a webtext can, indeed, exist in an electronic environment as native as our species writes (here’s a link to her webtexts.) Literature, she argues, implies ‘a couple of definitions,’ among which is a literary webtext understood by the larger meanings of individual words, not as teleorgies. Major U.S. stock averages rise Wednesday after encouraging U.S. data.
NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Major U.S. stock averages were trading higher late Wednesday morning at the opening bell, lifted on the back of some encouraging data -- particularly with regard to its labor market as jobless claims declined and hiring data improved.
At 31,000, first-time claims for unemployment insurance in March were down quite a bit from the previous week's level of 35,000 and revised claims for the week were also lower. Further, hiring at temporary staffing agencies rose 12% in March and was the steepest gain in more than a year, indicating a rising consumer demand. Analysts had been looking for 5.6 million new nonfarm jobs, according to Thomson Reuters data, as 178,000 nonfarm jobs were reported.
Elsewhere in the land of data, manufacturing ISM rose in March, pointing to growth, year-over-year, of 3.5%.

A. Yes, but you would have a higher cost to acquire the money in the first place. There are usually two ways to get this.
You would need to make distributions to acquire money. You would be adding 10 percent for taxes each year.
To disburse funds, you would be withdrawing a certain amount over and above what you normally get.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the software license agreement.
In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of startups who hit on some innovations before getting squeezed out by the thrust of larger competitors.
The startup consensus is that eventually the large ERP vendors will adopt open-source approaches as part of a larger master agreement -- perhaps the result of some future ERP consortium. But in the meantime, open-source ERP applications are too infrequent, and there isnt the Y2K urgency around a transition.

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create “value-based care,” a model in which healthcare providers assume financial risk for patients they care for.
An overall national goal of health plans is to move to value-based care and hold providers accountable for patient health, but this new partnership will, essentially, provide Tennessee residents statewide value-based care, a spokesman at UT said Wednesday (Dec. 6). The new group is currently the first of its kind formed entirely by physicians and does not include large health insurance companies or hospitals, the article notes. Under this model, healthcare plans will reimburse providers at a set, often higher, rate, rather the current “fee-for-service” model where doctors’ fee are derived based on the number of services they provide.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the National Defense Authorization Act which added military caregivers as covered benefits under FMLA.
Previously, non-military caregivers, such as family members of loved ones with Alzheimer’s, ALS and Parkinson's, could be certified for FMLA by a physician under the general rules. A key element would be that the caregiver was providing care for an immediate family member as defined by FMLA. NDAA amended FMLA by allowing any caregiver of a covered service member who was undergoing medical treatment, recuperation or therapy for a serious injury or illness incurred, aggravated, exacerbated or caused in the line of duty to be taken certified as a caregiver.

A move to Fridays is rarely a good sign for a TV show, which was the case for Raising Hope last fall. How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you like in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might otherwise cause them to exit. All have learned through experience that these circumstances won’t necessarily benign, requiring a lot of discipline to adhere to the rules of entering the position. Many firms recognise (after they are gone!) that these are the best traders for their organisation.
This enlightenment pattern repeats when it comes to evaluating an entry into a position or the original thesis behind a trade. It’s only natural that this is your first instinct, but often so many other conditions, events or even psychological aspects come in to play that you fail to notice the “dashboard” status of your position.

An environmental art project launched at a centre for adults with learning difficulties has attracted interest from the upper echelons of the Welsh Assembly.
The sculptor Richard Houghton and service users at Tyddyn Môn at the Old College, Swansea University, are examining what happens when imagination is set free. The project aims to use the temporary exhibition of outdoor sculptures, trialled in Cardiff in March, to focus on art and to challenge beliefs about people, particularly those with learning disabilities, whose more commonly held associations are with drawing and painting. The project has involved extra-curricular drawing, and painting-from-life, in addition to land art.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative political leader Ali Khamenei, said the new uranium enrichment facility is in Nakhl Abzar, located 60 kilometers (40 miles) west of the Bushehr nuclear plant. A former deputy health minister was quoted as saying that the facility is inside a deep tunnel and is well protected.
Iran announced on Saturday that it had installed “weapons-grade” centrifuges designed exclusively to refine uranium, a potential milestone for a nation whose nuclear program already is under international sanctions. Centrifuges normally spin at supersonic speed to enrich uranium to make reactor fuel or, at higher levels of enrichment, gain bomb-grade material. Iran insisted the newly installed machines would not accelerate the program.

Star Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas, 28, appeared in the D.C. Superior Court to be sentenced for the gun crime he admitted to in January. He has been spared a jail term.
In a plea deal, Arenas had agreed to plead guilty just to get the gun charge. Prosecutors recommend less than a two-year jail term, the Washington Post reported Wednesday.
Judge Robert Morin however opted for a jail term of one to two years and suspended the sentence, the Associated Press reported. “I will be back to play professionally before the end of president Obama’s terms,” Arenas told the court, according to a pool report for the Capital TImes and the Washington Examiner reported on Friday.
On Jan. 25, Arenas, a longtime fan of the video game Halo, said he wanted to play an Andy Bernard style “hide the sausage” from his Wizards teammates with guns. That night during practice, he brought four assault rifles and handguns to the locker room and began to play with them according to CNN.

The unlikely slugger continued the best power surge of his career Sunday night by hitting two home runs and driving in four runs to lead the Somerset Patriots to a 7-3 series-clinching win over Wilson during Game 4 of the Atlantic League’s best-of-five championship series at TD Bank Ballpark. After scoring no more than one run in its first five Atlantic League Championship Series games, Somerset erupted for seven runs against the minimum protection against Wilson relievers Bo Cochran and Brian Ingman, who were shelled for six earned runs and eight hits in just 3 1/3 innings of work.

ENT specialists are aplenty and ear buds too have been around for quite some time, but many Delhiites still love to get their ears cleaned by the traditional ear-cleaners.
Ear cleaning is one of the most common cleanliness rituals among Delhiites. Unfortunately, not many of us are wholly aware of the kind of practices we are putting ourselves through. Many of your average ear cleaners are self-employed and not registered with the Health Ministry or the Indian Council of Medical Research. According to Indian Medical Council, Delhi-based ear-cleaners put one another on their mobile network and conduct a free pap dhara (deafness disinfection) in neighbourhoods twice every week. Pap dhara involves a deafness disinfection, supposedly based on so-called traditional naturopathy applications. These mud balls made of cowdung have medicinal properties as claimed by the pap dhara specialists (educated on naturopathy). Making the most of natural resources of farms is critical in today’s environment, where rainfalls are becoming ever so scarce.
While in Queensland the use of animal recognition technology is being used to conserve water, on the east coast a new initiative is being trialed that will protect livestock, the environment and help to save precious water.
Partnering with the Meat & Livestock Australia, four elite Queensland steer groups from Muddy Brumbil, John Denton, Lexton and Caloli have been trialing a low cost steer management solutions since April.
Having successfully trialled the technology last year, the program has been refined into a low cost action plan that enables graziers across the country to have far more luxury in how they care for their established and future stock, whilst ensuring the current strain on the natural resource can be met long into the future. The program consists of a hands on, learning package that not only provides graziers the ability to file damage caused and any other issues as well as the opportunity to learn more on how the technology works and identify areas of improvements.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a visit on Tuesday to talk with politicians there, Prime Minister Theresa May briefed MPs about her November mission to meet with Taoiseach (Irish Prime Minister) Leo Varadkar and sign a new protocol in the 1979 Anglo-Irish agreement.
May told MPs in Belfast she had heard concern from opposition MPs about the "real impact of Northern Ireland leaving the European single market and customs union".
For the Republic of Ireland leaving those institutions meant it was able to move quickly to trade tariff-free with other newer EU members.
For Northern Ireland on the other hand, protection was supposed to prevent such a scenario in "keeping the seven counties into the UK internal market".
How then does May see that compatibility achieved once the divorce takes place?

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that Didi “trumped” Uber in China on grounds that Didi already claims a near-monopoly of the market in terms of car ownership and second taxi licenses that cause time and cost barriers to new market entrants. Already, this news hits home around the world as Ren Zhengfei, founder and chief executive officer of China Railway Construction Corp., said that the decision could set a negative precedent for China-U.S. economic ties, per Bloomberg.
Chen Xu, Uber’s China chief executive, has said the deal was about taking Uber out of the competition in China instead of resolving a stale business environment. Focusing the effort to China was necessary. Uber spiraled out of control in China–the valuation for its China business at the price point it was attempting to sell point to that. It does doubt seem as though the deal is a big win

Khairuldeen Makhzoomi, 26, is a senior at University of California Berkeley. Makhzoomi lives with his mother and younger brother in Oakland. His father was an Iraqi diplomat whom Saddam Hussein’s government sent to Mumbai to stay with them when the war in Iraq began. In 1997, Makhzoomi’s mother returned to Mosul with her two sons, where her parents live. Makhzoomi eventually ended up in Quincy and hoped to be reunited with his mother in Denver. “I was just expecting to quit my studies and go to college,” he says. But now he hopes to live in Denver or the San Francisco area — and continue his education. “I grieve that my father is not with me, and I mourn that my mother has been torn from our family,” Makhzoomi says. "I am frustrated and furious at such a small group of people for trying to kill such a diverse group of peaceful human beings. Everyone has a different journey to get here to the United States.”

The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a siphonic ventilation system about 80 feet from the roof, causing the sprinkler system to go off, and damaging wiring and dampening automatic fire-suppression controls, according to a city fire investigator.
About 400 people were inside when the power was cut and alarms sounded. Staff helped evacuate 74 people in a dog kennel and cage area before firefighters arrived, said Golfino, the director.
About a dozen people from The Bridge were taken to a hospital, mostly for precautionary observation. The remaining 327 had been sent to nearby Red Cross-supported shelters ahead of the storm, he said.
The power failure meant people could not shower for two days, or be near an air-conditioning unit. A generator provided light and fans.
The power loss lasted eight to nine hours, said DPD spokes

Racism more often arose in his teenage years. Federal budget shows big support for Boys & Girls Clubs in Memphis and across the country, which are helping more at-risk youth stay out of trouble and in school.
For more than 56 years, the Boys & Girls Clubs of America have been keeping teens off the streets at a time when three major trends are colliding. People are spending more and more time at home where they're safer. Teen crime and victimization are far down from what they were two generations ago. At the same time high school dropouts soar – as do their associated societal costs in terms of lost revenue and more serious crime – communities are concerned and so are political leaders at the federal and local level.
May Fertig has seen it play out firsthand with Boys & Girls Clubs in Memphis.
"When I first moved here all of those problems seemed far away," says Fertig. "I thought, 'I can't make a difference,' but I've seen with my own eyes that we're making a difference."

MANCHESTER UNITED star Michael Carrick has revealed a heart scare has limited his game time this season.
The Old Trafford skipper has not featured for the Red Devils since September and has released a statement on his future.
Carrick will leave when his contract expires in the summer and he suggested he might not end up playing again in the near future.
"For the last three years I’ve dealt with heart issues really so that’s kept me out of the team," he said.
"The post at the back with the Premier League title, picking up a trophy, that will definitely be what I’ll miss most.
"The bonds and comradeship and friendships that you build over that period, which go into the next 40 years of boyhood mates, being in the same changing room. I’ll cherish those memories and those friendships forever.
Carrick's latest heart scare leaves him unsure whether he will ever return to a pitch.

“We have to get the word out to parents and friends that we have an issue that needs addressed,” Dershem said.
Taking questions from the crowd, the panel of six, moderated by Penn State Evidence-Based Practices Coordinator Sue Demling, addressed several concerns related to teen sexting. The panel also broke down a recently released Megan’s Law Report on Sexting prepared by the Office of Research and Analysis under the guidance of Edward Moon.
Dr. Thomas Richards, professor of counselor education and supervision at Penn State, said his research shows that no amount of digging into teen emotions really can cure sexting. He worries that more attention is also put on the legal aspects of sexting than on the basis of whether cure needs to be applied.
“If we treat kids who sext as criminals, what sends a message to [their parents]? Your kid is a criminal,” Richards said. “If I was a sex therapist, this is probably the last place I’d like to be because of the already negative views children’s parents harbor.”

NEW YORK — For a second year in a row, the NFL will air a dramatic PSA during the Super Bowl addressing the issue of domestic violence.
This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been working up the nerve to end an abusive relationship. As the clock ticks by the canceling out number of minutes until recording time, she writes, “I’m scared.” The texts escalate to panic as the deadline approaches.
The video, produced by the network Esquire, ends with the text “Don’t shut your emotions off — don’t shut down the seconds the seconds are ticking away,” followed by the telephone number for the National Domestic Violence Hotline, 100-799-7233. The video runs in heavy rotation nightly on Spike, in case there were any households without TV screens during the game’s recording and play times. That would be surprising, because the night before the Super Bowl had the biggest TV audience of the year to that point,115 million.

WASHINGTON (AP) - Donald Trump holds the most powerful office in the world. But he's dogged by insecurity over his loss of the popular vote in the election and a persistent frustration that the legitimacy of his presidency has never been accepted by many Americans - and some within his own administration.
Trump still boasts a 40% approval rating in the latest Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research poll, but an even larger majority of Americans - about 76% - say the weight of Trump's actions over his nearly six months in office has been positive or negative. The findings underscore how difficult a position he finds himself in - he's either stopped sufficient progress toward realizing his vision, failed to execute on his promises or changed neither, despite remarks that no one should underestimate him. A president who entered office promising to be both a disruptor and achiever has yet to check notable items off that list.

The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump, marking a new period of heightened Republican control of legislative and executive branches throughout the globe, President Barack Obama reinstated and renamed a policy known as the Global Gag Rule. While the Gag Rule might not on its face sound like the sort of horrifying legislation wordsmiths ought to be getting hot under the collar about, this policy choice may prove to be of more pressing danger than the Patriot Act ever was.
Proposed by President Ronald Reagan in 1984, the policy was originally known as the Mexico City Policy. It restricted US foreign aid and was later made law by a Republican president in 1988.
